summary: This is an email chain from August 2008 between U.S. Attorney's Office (USAFLS) personnel, including Alex Acosta, discussing a letter from attorney Brad Edwards regarding the Jeffrey Epstein non-prosecution agreement. The emails discuss the reasons victims were not consulted, the confidentiality provision, and a planned meeting with Edwards.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Author of the email, recalling that contacting victims would compromise them as witnesses and referencing Epstein's arguments about victims seeking money.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney who sent a letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the Epstein non-prosecution agreement, requesting agreement on facts about victim consultation and seeking transcripts and FBI 302s.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the non-prosecution agreement; argued that victims were motivated by money, and entered guilty pleas in state court.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, was involved in the prosecution agreement with Epstein, referencing Epstein's arguments about victims.
Edwards is an attorney corresponding with the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the Epstein case and the non-prosecution agreement.
Acosta and Edwards are in correspondence regarding the Epstein case, with Edwards requesting information and a meeting.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement Reached
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office and Jeffrey Epstein reached a non-prosecution agreement, which included a confidentiality provision.

events.title: Email Discussion on Victim Consultation
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discuss the reasons victims were not consulted in the Epstein case, citing the Crime Victims Rights Act and confidentiality provisions.

events.title: Planned Call to Brad Edwards
events.description: A U.S. Attorney's Office representative plans to call Brad Edwards to inform him they cannot produce the agreement due to confidentiality and to arrange a meeting.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office, under Alex Acosta, believed contacting Epstein's victims would compromise them as witnesses.
Jeffrey Epstein argued that the victims were motivated by money, influencing the office's decision not to discuss liability with them.
The victims were not consulted in the non-prosecution agreement process, with the exception of FBI agents meeting with one victim in September 2007.
The confidentiality provision in the agreement was cited as a reason for not being able to produce the agreement to Brad Edwards.
Brad Edwards requested agreement on facts regarding the deferral of prosecution and victim consultation, as well as free transcripts and FBI 302s.
